examples.description: An overview of the foundational pillars of language structure, illustrated with the concept of 'a house'.

row_description.text: The basic sounds and writing of the word 'house'.
Inflecting 'house' to 'in the house' reveals sound changes like vowel harmony.
The genitive case ('of the house') shows how different stems are used for inflection.

examples.description: Examples of basic grapheme-to-phoneme correspondence across languages.

row_description.text: A simple word with common consonants and vowels.
A word containing a silent or historically pronounced letter.

examples.description: Examples of common phonological rules that cause sounds to change in different grammatical contexts.

row_description.text: Vowel Harmony: Vowels in suffixes change to match vowels in the stem (e.g., back vs. front).
Consonant Gradation: A consonant in the stem weakens in certain grammatical forms (e.g., nominative 'kukka' vs. genitive 'kukan').

examples.description: Examples of how word stems are formed or altered to create new words or to inflect.

row_description.text: Derivational Morphology: Forming a noun (agent) from a verb stem (e.g., 'to write' -> 'writer').
Inflectional Stems: Using different stems for different grammatical functions (e.g., nominative vs. oblique cases).

examples.description: An overview of the Objective Pillar, which concerns entities and their properties.

row_description.text: An adjective modifying the noun, 'the good king'.
Replacing the noun phrase with a pronoun, 'he'.

examples.description: An overview of the core properties of entities (nouns).

row_description.text: A noun classified by animacy, 'the woman'.
A noun marked for plural number, 'the women'.
A noun in a specific case, 'the woman's (book)'.

examples.description: Examples illustrating the different ways nouns are classified.

row_description.text: An animate noun as the subject.
An inanimate noun as the subject.

examples.description: Examples contrasting animate (living, agentive) and inanimate (non-living, non-agentive) nouns and their grammatical treatment.

row_description.text: Inanimate subject in a state of being.

examples.description: Examples illustrating grammatical gender, a system where nouns are classified into categories (e.g., masculine, feminine, neuter) that can affect the form of agreeing words like adjectives and articles.

row_description.text: Masculine noun with agreeing adjective: 'the big man'.
Feminine noun with agreeing adjective: 'the big woman'.
Neuter noun with agreeing adjective: 'the big house'.
Gendered inanimate object (masculine): 'The sun is bright'.
Gendered inanimate object (feminine): 'The moon is bright'.

examples.description: Examples showing how languages mark definiteness, distinguishing between a specific, identifiable entity ('the book') and a non-specific one ('a book').

row_description.text: Definite with adjective (weak declension): 'The good man reads.'
Indefinite with adjective (strong declension): 'A good man reads.'

examples.description: Examples illustrating grammatical number, which indicates the quantity of entities, such as singular (one), plural (more than one), and dual (exactly two).
An overview of the various functions a noun can serve in a sentence, indicated by grammatical case or by prepositions/postpositions.

row_description.text: The core syntactic roles, like the subject of a sentence.
Location or movement within or from within something.
Location or movement on or near the surface of something.
The state or role of being something.
The means or instrument by which an action is performed.

examples.description: Examples of the core grammatical cases that define the primary syntactic relationships between nouns and the verb, such as subject, object, and possession.

row_description.text: The predicate nominative after a linking verb.
The direct object of the verb.
A partial, incomplete, or negated object.
Direct address to a proper noun.

examples.description: The nominative case marks the subject of a finite verb. It is the 'base' form of a noun, indicating who or what is performing the action or is in a particular state.

row_description.text: Singular subject of an intransitive verb.
Plural subject of an intransitive verb.
Singular subject of a transitive verb.
Plural subject of a transitive verb.
Singular subject in a passive construction.
Plural subject in a passive construction.

examples.description: The genitive case primarily indicates possession or relationship, often translated as 'of' or with an apostrophe-s ('s) in English. It answers the question 'whose?'.

row_description.text: Partitive genitive (of the whole): 'a piece of the bread'.
Objective genitive (object of an action): 'fear of the gods'.
Subjective genitive (subject of an action): 'the army's arrival'.
Genitive of quality/description: 'a woman of great wisdom'.
Genitive of definition: 'the city of Rome'.

examples.description: The accusative case marks the direct object of a transitive verb—the entity that directly receives the action. It can also mark motion towards, duration of time, and the subject of an infinitive.

row_description.text: Simple direct object (singular): 'The farmer sees the river.'
Simple direct object (plural): 'The farmer sees the rivers.'
Direct object pronoun: 'The farmer sees it.'
Motion towards (object of preposition): 'He walks to the city.'
Extent of time: 'They waited for many hours.'
Extent of space: 'The soldier ran three miles.'
Subject of infinitive: 'I know the man to be good.'
Cognate accusative: 'He lived a good life.'

examples.description: The partitive case, prominent in languages like Finnish, marks a partial, incomplete, or negated object. It indicates 'some of' something, an ongoing action without a specified result, or the object in a negative sentence.

row_description.text: Negated object: 'I do not want coffee.'
With numbers (other than one): 'I bought two books.'
Ongoing action (irresultative): 'He is writing a letter.'
Completed action (resultative contrast): 'He wrote the letter.'
With verbs of emotion: 'I love this city.'
Subject of existential sentence (uncountable): 'There is sand on the beach.'

examples.description: The dative case marks the indirect object of a verb, the recipient of an action. It answers the question 'to whom?' or 'for whom?'. It is also governed by certain verbs, adjectives, and prepositions.

row_description.text: Indirect object (recipient): 'I give the book to the woman.'
Dative of reference (for whom): 'The mother bakes a cake for the child.'
With special verbs: 'He helps the man.'
With adjectives: 'The dog is friendly to the cat.'
Dative of possession: 'The man has a book.' (Lit: 'To the man is a book.')
Ethical dative: 'He plucked me a flower.'
Dative of agent: 'The work must be done by me.'
Dative of separation: 'He took the sword from the soldier.'

examples.description: The vocative case is used for direct address, to call out to or name a person or thing being spoken to. Its form is often identical to the nominative, but some languages have distinct forms.

row_description.text: Simple address, singular male name: 'Marcus, come here!'
Simple address, singular female name: 'Julia, listen!'
Address to a common noun: 'O sailor, where are you going?'
Address to a group: 'Romans, lend me your ears.'
Address to a god: 'O Jupiter, save us!'
Address with an adjective: 'My dear son, you are wise.'
Vocative in a list: 'Caesar, Brutus, and Cassius, come forward.'

examples.description: This section covers cases that describe location or movement within, into, or out of a space. These are highly developed in Finno-Ugric languages but are typically handled by prepositions in Indo-European languages.

row_description.text: Inessive (static location inside): 'The fish is in the water.'
Inessive (static location inside): 'We live in a city.'
Elative (movement out of): 'The bird flies out of the cage.'
Elative (movement out of): 'He comes from the house.'
Illative (movement into): 'The man goes into the forest.'
Illative (movement into): 'She puts water into the glass.'

examples.description: The inessive case indicates static location within a defined space. It answers the question 'in where?'.

row_description.text: Simple location: 'The book is in the bag.'
Location in a building: 'The king is in the castle.'
Location in a country: 'I live in Finland.'
Location in a body of water: 'There are fish in the lake.'
Abstract location: 'There is strength in unity.'
Temporal location: 'My birthday is in January.'
Wearing clothes: 'The ring is in his finger.'
With a plural noun: 'The children are playing in the rooms.'

examples.description: The elative case indicates movement 'out of' or 'from' a location. It answers the question 'from where?'. It can also indicate the source or topic of something.

row_description.text: Movement from a container: 'He took the apple from the basket.'
Movement from a building: 'She came out of the church.'
Source of information: 'I read about it in the newspaper.'
Topic of discussion: 'What do you think of this book?'
Material composition: 'The sword is made of steel.'
Abstract source: 'He woke from a deep sleep.'
Movement from a group: 'He came from the soldiers.'

examples.description: The illative case indicates movement 'into' a location. It answers the question 'into where?'.

row_description.text: Movement into a container: 'He put the apple into the basket.'
Movement into a building: 'She went into the church.'
Movement to a country: 'We are traveling to Sweden.'
Movement into a body of water: 'The boy jumped into the river.'
Abstract destination: 'An idea came into my mind.'
Movement into a group: 'The general rode into his soldiers.'
With a plural noun: 'The birds flew into the trees.'
Purpose or goal: 'He went to war.'

examples.description: This section covers cases that describe location or movement on, at, onto, or from the surface of something. These are prominent in Finno-Ugric languages and are typically handled by prepositions in Indo-European languages.

row_description.text: Adessive (static location on/at): 'The book is on the table.'
Adessive (static location on/at): 'We are at the station.'
Ablative (movement from off): 'The book fell from the table.'
Ablative (movement from off): 'He came from the roof.'
Allative (movement onto): 'The book fell onto the table.'
Allative (movement onto): 'He went to the roof.'

examples.description: The adessive case indicates static location 'on' or 'at' a place or object. It can also express possession or the instrument used for an action in some languages.

row_description.text: Location on a surface: 'The cat is on the roof.'
Location at a place: 'I am at the market.'
With a person: 'The keys are with me.'
Plural location: 'The sheep are on the hills.'
Abstract location: 'He is at a concert.'

examples.description: The ablative case indicates movement 'from' or 'from off' a surface or location. It answers the question 'from where?'. It can also express cause, agent, or comparison.

row_description.text: Movement from a surface: 'He took the cup from the table.'
Movement from a place: 'The train arrived from the city.'
Receiving from someone: 'I received a gift from my mother.'
Originating from a place: 'The wind blows from the sea.'
Leaving a place: 'He departed from the shore.'
Plural source: 'The water flows from the mountains.'
Abstract source: 'The smell comes from the kitchen.'
Time: 'From that day, he was king.'

examples.description: The allative case indicates movement 'onto' a surface or 'to' a location or person. It answers the question 'to where?' or 'to whom?'.

row_description.text: Movement onto a surface: 'The cat jumped onto the roof.'
Movement to a place: 'We are going to the market.'
Giving to someone: 'I wrote a letter to the king.'
Approaching something: 'He walked to the shore.'
Plural destination: 'The path leads to the mountains.'
Abstract destination: 'He went to the meeting.'
Directed action: 'He shouted to the dog.'
Recipient of a feeling: 'This is important to me.'

examples.description: This section covers cases that describe the state of being something (essive) or the process of becoming something (translative). These are often called 'marginal' cases as they are less common than core grammatical or locative cases.

row_description.text: Essive (state of being): 'He works as a teacher.'
Essive (state of being): 'The water is frozen (as ice).'
Translative (change of state): 'He became a teacher.'
Translative (change of state): 'The water turned into ice.'

examples.description: The essive case describes a temporary state, role, or function, often translated as 'as a...'. It indicates the capacity in which someone or something exists or acts.

row_description.text: Role or function: 'He is here as a guest.'
Comparison: 'He is tall for a child (as a child).'
With possessive suffix: 'I will be there as your friend.'
With a name: 'They call him John.'

examples.description: The translative case indicates a change of state or role, often translated as 'into a...' or 'becoming a...'. It marks the result of a transformation.

row_description.text: Change of role: 'She was elected president.'
Change of state (physical): 'The milk turned sour.'
Change of state (abstract): 'The situation became difficult.'
Purpose or goal: 'He studied to become a doctor.'
Time limit: 'I will finish this by Friday.'
Plural result: 'They grew into strong men.'
Intended purpose: 'He bought it for a gift.'

examples.description: This section covers cases related to instrumentality, absence, and accompaniment. These concepts are often expressed through dedicated case endings in some languages, while others rely on prepositions.

row_description.text: Instructive (means): 'He built the house with his own hands.'
Comitative (accompaniment): 'The woman came with her husband.'
Comitative (accompaniment): 'The king fought with his army.'

examples.description: The instructive case (or its equivalent, the instrumental) indicates the means or instrument by which an action is performed. It answers the question 'with what?' or 'by what means?'.

row_description.text: To speak with a loud voice.

examples.description: The abessive case indicates the absence of something, equivalent to the English preposition 'without'.
The comitative case indicates accompaniment, equivalent to the English preposition 'with' or 'together with'. It specifies who or what is accompanying the subject.

row_description.text: A house with all its furniture.
I will go with a friend.
To speak with a heavy heart.
He lives with his wife and children.

examples.description: An overview of how entities are modified by qualities (adjectives), quantities (numerals), and comparisons (degrees).
Adjectives are words that describe the qualities or states of being of nouns. They typically agree with the noun they modify in properties like gender, number, and case.
Numerals are words that express a number or quantity. They can be cardinal (one, two, three), ordinal (first, second, third), or other types. They often agree with the noun they modify.
Adjectives can be inflected to show degrees of comparison: the positive (the base form), the comparative (a higher degree), and the superlative (the highest degree).
An overview of pronouns, which are words that substitute for nouns or noun phrases.
Personal pronouns refer to specific persons or things. They change form based on person (1st, 2nd, 3rd), number (singular, plural, dual), gender, and case.

row_description.text: 2nd person plural dative: 'I give this to you (all).'

examples.description: Demonstrative pronouns point to specific entities, indicating their location in space or time relative to the speaker. They distinguish between 'this' (proximal) and 'that' (distal).

row_description.text: Proximal singular nominative: 'This is a book.'
Distal singular nominative: 'That is a house.'
Proximal plural genitive: 'the color of these'
Distal plural dative: 'I give it to those.'

examples.description: Interrogative pronouns are used to ask questions. The specific pronoun used often depends on what is being asked about (e.g., a person, a thing, a choice).

row_description.text: Asking about a person (subject): 'Who is that?'
Asking about a thing (subject): 'What is this?'
Asking about a choice: 'Which do you want?'
Asking about possession: 'Whose book is this?'

examples.description: Relative pronouns introduce relative clauses, which modify a noun (the antecedent). Common relative pronouns include 'who', 'which', 'that', and 'whose'.

row_description.text: Subject of the clause: 'The man who lives here is my friend.'
Object of the clause: 'The man whom I saw is my friend.'
Inanimate object: 'The book which I am reading is good.'
Possessive: 'The man whose house is big is my friend.'

examples.description: Indefinite pronouns refer to non-specific people or things. They include words like 'someone', 'anything', 'nobody', 'everyone'.

row_description.text: Referring to a person: 'Someone is at the door.'
Referring to a thing: 'I need something.'

examples.description: An overview of the Predicate Pillar, which concerns actions, states, and their modifications.
An overview of the core properties of verbs, which express actions or states of being.

row_description.text: Non-finite Forms: 'To see is to believe.'

examples.description: Temporality describes how an action is situated in time (tense) and how its duration or completion is viewed (aspect).
Tense marks the time of an action relative to the moment of speaking. The primary tenses are present, past, and future, though many languages have more complex systems.

row_description.text: Future Perfect: 'The bird will have sung.'

examples.description: Aspect describes the internal temporal constituency of a situation, such as its duration, completion, or repetition. It is distinct from tense, which locates the situation in time.

row_description.text: Perfective Aspect (completed action): 'I read the book.'
Imperfective Aspect (ongoing action): 'I was reading a book.'
Iterative Aspect (repeated action): 'He knocked on the door.'

examples.description: Modality, or mood, expresses the speaker's attitude toward the factuality or likelihood of the proposition being expressed. It covers states like reality, possibility, necessity, and obligation.
The indicative mood is used to make factual statements or to ask questions about facts. It is the most common mood, representing an action or state as real or certain.

row_description.text: Simple future statement: 'The sun will shine.'
Negative present statement: 'The sun does not shine.'
Statement with a copula: 'The sun is a star.'
Statement with a transitive verb: 'The sun warms the earth.'
Statement with a plural subject: 'The stars shine.'

examples.description: The subjunctive and conditional moods express non-factual situations, such as wishes, possibilities, hypotheses, and conditions contrary to fact.

row_description.text: Hypothetical condition: 'If I were a king...'
Polite request/suggestion: 'I would like some water.'
Purpose clause: 'He fights so that they may be free.'
Command in subordinate clause: 'He demands that she leave.'
Result of a condition: '...he would be rich.'
Contrary-to-fact past condition: 'If he had known, he would have come.'
Doubt/Uncertainty: 'I doubt that he is coming.'

examples.description: The imperative mood is used to express direct commands, requests, or prohibitions.

row_description.text: Command with pronoun: 'Give it to me!'

examples.description: The potential mood expresses that an action or state is probable or likely, but not certain. It is a distinct morphological category in Finnish, while other languages typically use modal verbs or adverbs.

row_description.text: Simple potential statement: 'He will probably arrive today.'
Negative potential statement: 'He probably won't arrive today.'
Past potential: 'He would probably have arrived.'
Potential with transitive verb: 'I can probably lift it.'
Potential passive: 'The letter can probably be sent.'
Expressing a guess: 'It is likely raining now.'
Expressing a polite opinion: 'That is probably the best way.'

examples.description: Voice describes the relationship between the action expressed by a verb and the participants identified by its arguments (subject, object, etc.).

row_description.text: Active Voice: The subject performs the action.
Passive Voice: The subject receives the action.
Middle Voice: The subject acts on itself.

examples.description: The active voice indicates that the subject of the verb is the agent, the one performing the action.

row_description.text: Simple transitive: 'The dog chases the cat.'
With dative object: 'The woman gives a book to the man.'
Future tense: 'I will build a house.'
With modal verb: 'They can see the mountain.'
With a negative object: 'He eats no bread.'

examples.description: The passive voice is used when the subject of the sentence is the recipient of the action, rather than the performer. The performer (agent) can be specified (often with a preposition like 'by') or omitted.

row_description.text: Simple passive: 'The cat is chased by the dog.'
With dative recipient: 'A book was given to the man.'
Future passive: 'The letter will be written.'
With modal verb: 'The mountain can be seen.'
Passive with inanimate agent: 'The tree was struck by lightning.'
Impersonal passive: 'It was danced all night.'
Passive infinitive: 'The house needs to be built.'

examples.description: The middle voice indicates that the subject both performs and is affected by the action. It often overlaps with reflexive or anticausative constructions, where an action happens to the subject without an external agent.

Verbs are often grouped into classes or conjugations based on how they form their tenses and other inflections. These classes can be determined by the vowel of the stem or the type of endings they take.
An overview of non-finite verb forms, which do not show tense or person and include infinitives, participles, and gerunds/supines.

row_description.text: Infinitive: The basic form of a verb, 'to do'.
Participle: A verb form used as an adjective, 'the doing one'.
Gerund/Supine: A verb form that functions as a noun, 'the act of doing'.

examples.description: The infinitive is the base form of a verb, often used as a noun, to express purpose, or with modal verbs.

row_description.text: Infinitive as subject: 'To see is to believe.'
Infinitive as object: 'I want to learn.'
Infinitive with modal verb: 'He must go.'
Infinitive of purpose: 'I came to see.'

examples.description: Participles are verb forms that can function as adjectives or be used to form compound tenses. They typically have active (present) and passive (past) forms.

row_description.text: Present active participle as adjective: 'the running water'
Past passive participle as adjective: 'a written letter'
In a compound tense: 'The letter has been written.'
In an absolute construction: 'With the sun having risen, the birds began to sing.'

examples.description: Gerunds and supines are verbal nouns. A gerund typically functions as the subject or object of a sentence (like English '-ing' forms). A supine, found in Latin, is a verbal noun used to express purpose.

row_description.text: Gerund as object of preposition: 'He is tired of waiting.'
Latin gerundive of obligation: 'Carthage must be destroyed.'
Latin supine of purpose: 'They came to ask for peace.'

examples.description: Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs, providing information about manner, place, time, frequency, or degree.

row_description.text: Modifying an adjective: 'It is very cold.'
Modifying another adverb: 'He runs very quickly.'

examples.description: An overview of the Subjective Pillar, which concerns how clauses are structured and related to express complete thoughts, questions, commands, and complex ideas.

row_description.text: The basic arrangement of a factual statement.
Using particles to form a question or add emphasis.

examples.description: An overview of the fundamental components of a single clause, including word order, negation, interrogation, possession, and the use of adpositions.

row_description.text: The typical arrangement of subject, verb, and objects.
How a clause is made negative.
How a clause is turned into a question.
Words that specify location or relation (prepositions/postpositions).

examples.description: Word order refers to the conventional sequence of syntactic constituents in a clause. While many languages prefer a Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) order, others use different arrangements for grammatical or stylistic reasons.

row_description.text: V2 (Verb-Second): 'Today the farmer plows the field.'
Question with inversion: 'Does the farmer plow the field?'

examples.description: This section covers negation, the process of making a clause negative to deny a proposition. This can be done with a dedicated negative verb or a particle.

row_description.text: The man does not see the house.

examples.description: Negation is often achieved with a specific negative particle (like 'not' or 'no') or a dedicated negative verb (like in Finnish).

row_description.text: Predicate nominative negation: 'He is not a king.'
Negating a simple verb: 'She does not sing.'
Negating a past action: 'We did not go.'
Negating a future action: 'They will not come.'
Negating an adjective: 'The book is not red.'
Double negative: 'I didn't see nobody.' (non-standard English)

examples.description: This section covers interrogation, the formation of questions. This can involve inverting word order, using interrogative particles, or specific question words.
Yes/no questions are often formed using an interrogative particle (a clitic attached to the verb) or by inverting the subject and verb.

row_description.text: Question with auxiliary verb: 'Does she know?'
Question with perfect tense: 'Have they eaten?'
Tag question: 'You are coming, aren't you?'
Rhetorical question: 'Surely you are not leaving?'
Alternative question: 'Are you coming or going?'

examples.description: Languages use various strategies to indicate possession, including case endings (genitive), possessive verbs ('to have'), possessive pronouns/adjectives, and possessive suffixes.

row_description.text: Possessive Verb: 'The man has a house.'
Dative of Possession: 'To me is a house.'

examples.description: Adpositions (prepositions and postpositions) are words that link a noun phrase to another word in the sentence, typically indicating a relationship of space, time, or logic. Prepositions come before their noun object, while postpositions come after.
An overview of how clauses are connected, either as equals (coordination) or with one dependent on the other (subordination).

row_description.text: A dependent clause joined to a main clause by 'while'.

examples.description: Coordination links two or more elements of equal syntactic status, such as words, phrases, or independent clauses. This is typically done with coordinating conjunctions like 'and', 'but', and 'or'.

row_description.text: Additive coordination: 'The sun shines and the birds sing.'
Adversative coordination: 'He is poor, but he is happy.'
Disjunctive coordination: 'Will you stay or will you go?'

examples.description: Subordination links a dependent (subordinate) clause to a main (independent) clause. The subordinate clause cannot stand alone as a complete sentence and is introduced by a subordinating conjunction or a relative pronoun.

row_description.text: 'I saw the man who sold the book.'
'If it rains, we will stay home.'
'He works so that he can live.'

examples.description: Relative clauses modify a noun (the antecedent) and are introduced by a relative pronoun (who, which, that, etc.). They provide additional information about the noun.

row_description.text: Subject relative pronoun: 'The woman who is singing is my sister.'
Object relative pronoun: 'The book that I read was interesting.'
Possessive relative pronoun: 'The man whose car was stolen called the police.'
Object of preposition: 'The city in which I live is beautiful.'
Non-restrictive clause: 'My brother, who lives in Rome, is a doctor.'
Omitted relative pronoun: 'The book I read was interesting.'

examples.description: Conditional clauses express a condition and its consequence. They are typically introduced by a subordinating conjunction like 'if' (or its equivalent).

row_description.text: Present real condition (indicative): 'If it rains, we will stay home.'
Present contrary-to-fact (subjunctive): 'If I were you, I would go.'
Past contrary-to-fact: 'If he had studied, he would have passed.'
Negative condition: 'Unless you hurry, you will be late.'
Zero conditional (general truth): 'If you heat ice, it melts.'
Future less vivid: 'Should you see him, tell him to call.'
Mixed conditional: 'If I had saved money, I would be rich now.'

examples.description: Purpose clauses express the purpose or goal of the action in the main clause. They are often introduced by conjunctions like 'so that', 'in order to', or are expressed with infinitives or other non-finite verb forms.

row_description.text: Purpose with infinitive: 'He works to earn money.'
Purpose with 'so that': 'He works so that he may live.'
Negative purpose: 'He works quietly lest he wake the baby.'
Latin Supine of purpose: 'They came to complain.'

examples.description: Particles are small, uninflected words that add nuance or perform a grammatical function. They can indicate focus, form questions, or express attitudes.

row_description.text: Focus on subject: 'He went to the store.'
Question particle: 'Is it you who is coming?'
